posts.message:
Apple, Google, Microsoft: Where does the money come from?
Wow, Apple makes 55% of its revenue from iPhone but only 13% from Mac.
Also, at WWDC Tim Cook said that Mac has an install base on 80 million users. This is the same size as Windows 8/8.1 install base. In other words, nothing.
To put it another way, all the Apple laptops you see at trendy coffee shops and those in Movies and TV shows are all the Apple laptops there is, it's not the tip of any iceberg :D
http://www.zdnet.com/apple-google-microsoft-where-does-the-money-come-from-7000026043/
posts.caption: www.zdnet.com
posts.description: If you want to know why big tech companies act the way they do, follow the money. Based on the latest SEC filings, Apple's still a successful hardware company, and Google's still in the advertising business. Meanwhile, how's that "devices and services" shift working for Microsoft?

posts.message:
Top Internet and Browser vendors are working on a draft for HTTP2: a new version of the protocol at the foundation of the Internet.
Daniel Stenberg (author and maintainer of cURL, who works for Mozilla) shares some of the details about the process and current state of draft.
Things I learned:
- HTTP2 will be binary, not text based.
- HTTP2 started with Google's SPDY protocol.
- You can enable HTTP2 today if you're using Firefox (I turned it on in Nightly). I think Twitter already supports HTTP2 (but I'm not sure).
- So far, HTTP2 will allow for non-SSL connection. There's a push to make SSL/TLS required for all connection (which I'm in a favor of, I have to say).
- Main goal seems to be to reduce number of trips between server and client.
He put together a PDF with all the details. Check it out. It's not all technical details but also history of HTTP and how we got here.
http://daniel.haxx.se/http2/
posts.caption: daniel.haxx.se
posts.description: This document describes http2 at a technical and protocol level. Background, the protocol, the implementations and the future.
